title: 103_s2277
content: Authorization of major medical facility projects and leases. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility projects and leases for the Department of Veterans Affairs, including those not previously authorized or funded before fiscal year 1995. Additionally, the Secretary may undertake additional projects as specified in submitted documents to Congress. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility projects and leases, including new construction projects in Charleston, South Carolina, and Phoenix, Arizona, funded by the Health Care Investment Fund for fiscal year 1995. These authorizations apply to projects not previously funded before 1995. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out major medical facility projects in addition to those authorized in previous sections. This includes constructing an ambulatory care/support services facility and repairing earthquake-damaged facilities at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Sepulveda, California, with specified funding amounts. Authorization of appropriations for major medical facility projects, including construction and repairs at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Sepulveda, California. Authorization of appropriations for major medical facility projects in fiscal year 1995, including funds for construction and leases. Projects can only be carried out using specific funds allocated for that purpose. Authorization of appropriations for major medical facility projects in fiscal year 1995, limited to specific funds allocated for construction and leases. Funds appropriated to the Construction, Major Projects account for fiscal year 1994 for a category of activity not specific to a project. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is allowed to reorganize the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Sepulveda, California without waiting for congressional approval due to earthquake damage in 1994. The Senate passed the reorganization of the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Sepulveda, California on August 19, 1994.
